title: How do students get so deeply inspired to study day and night to get into IIT? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a question which has been asked and answered a zillion time. I’m answering this question completely from a personal point of view. I know a person who gave his day and night to prepare for IIT. His efforts got him a great result. He did his B.Tech. in Computer Science from IIT Roorkee, which was his dream come true. Let me explain who he is, how it happened, and why students get deeply inspired to get into an IIT. As I have also begun my journey to get into an IIT, and I have two people to thank for that. One is my friend, Komal, about whom I have mentioned in my previous answer as well. The other inspiration is my friend’s brother, Aditya – who fulfilled his IIT dream. When it comes to IIT, it’s considered an elite institute to study in. The process of getting there is, of course, really difficult. But it’s the passion and motivation which inspires students to achieve their dream. In this case, it was my brother’s friend Aditya’s tireless hard work and passion, which helped him in cracking JEE. Being focused from the very beginning, he started his preparations right after his 10th and dedicated himself sincerely to studies. The most inspiring thing about him was that he did not appear for any other entrance exam apart from JEE. He was so confident of cracking JEE at once, and he did it too. Whenever he came to our house to meet my brother, he discussed Engineering prospects and colleges. Being a Commerce student, my brother used to get bored due to his talks. But I was always attentive enough to listen to him. I even asked him a lot of questions related to college entrances. I could see the passion in his eyes and voice whenever he discussed IIT. He was like damn sure that all he wants is an admission to an IIT. When the time came, and he took JEE, he got a brilliant AIR and got himself into IIT Roorkee for B.Tech in Computer Science specialization. Today, he is working for a Bangalore based MNC. Whenever my brother discusses him, I feel inspired. Last Diwali, he came to our house, and I asked him his success recipe, so he said you only need two things to achieve what you want- hard work and passion. He also reminded me to practice and revise regularly. He also suggested that online learning classes are also a great way to maximize your chances. During his time, he took coaching from FIITJEE. He mentioned that FIITJEE has now started with online coaching as well. It’s known as mypat, which I found to be a nice concept. For aspirants like me, it can be a perfect platform. You can visit their website to know more. They provide mock tests and also have an open community to discuss any doubts. It’s worth trying for sure!

Ever since childhood, my parents have been critical of my studies. My mother used to teach me every day during the initial years of my schooling. Then my parents got me into coaching where I would go to classes and give weekly tests. Otherwise, I would play computer games. I didn’t have any ambition as such. I didn’t know what I will do later in life. I didn’t know what a career is. I was doing what my parents asked me to do, study. And I was fine with it. I didn’t know what stream I would choose after 10th. I didn’t know what commerce, economics and arts streams are like. Never got an opportunity to study these. My father got me write a science talent exam through which I got a good scholarship. I guess that was the first time I did something good enough to make my parents feel proud of me. I was happy. And that's how I chose my stream PCM. For I who was unknown of how life at IIT would be like and opportunities that I would get there, the inspiration came from a basic desire to solve problems. I didn’t know what engineering disciplines were, skills that the world ultimately requires from you. My world ended with PCM because I thought all the world problems could be solved just like questions in Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics. Solving problems, getting good ranks in tests and seeing my parents happy after each result. Just that, as if that is the only goal of my life.  I believe it is OK if someone does not want to choose a career path on his own and let his parents decide that. He respects the fact that his parents are putting their hard-earned money for a reason which will eventually make him happy and make his life better. And in return, he wants to study hard and make his parents feel happy for him. A reason as simple as this can be an inspiration than thinking about the bigger prospects of getting into IIT. Perhaps for many, the inspiration to study day and night is for securing a good rank in JEE and not for getting into a good IIT. And there is a difference between the two.

The answer to the question can be given only after you've reached in an IIT or cleared JEE Advance. Let me give you a brief view of life after doing your JEE paper. Sleep at 4 a.m. or later. Or don't sleep. Nobody's going to restrict you. Nobody's going to scold you. Nothing. Your parents would be rather happy to see you enjoying after all the hard work. And the best part - they won't wake you up early ( I slept till 2–3p.m without any issues. Although you'll still have to bathe daily. :D ) Hang out with friends late till night. come and go whenever you want, wherever you want ( Don't go to unsafe places, your parents are still parents ). And the best day, when your result is out. The proud look on the faces of your parents. And all the calls from your relatives and friends, enough to feel like a Superstar. Everyone congratulates you on phone, Facebook, messages etc. And the pics in the newspaper with your parents name in it, that's the icing on the cake. You realise that the hard work pays off in the end. Now, life at IIT. One word, mind-blowing! You come to college thinking this must be a collection of nerds and bookish worms. Instead you find people doing everything except studies( there are people who study though, some just don't learn -_-). You come to college thinking of pursuing an old interest and get attracted to a new one even more. And before you realise it, the whole day is over in classes and the activities and late night brainy discussions on an interesting topic(not from the syllabus, of course not). And the pool of friends you get, with the unrestricted environment(unlike other colleges) you can have those night out you always dreamt about, or a weekend elopement). All this is just a glimpse. It can only be experienced by one.

For many of us it was like a ‘do or die’ situation. In India, if you want to get the best technical education, I can say it, hands down, there is no place better than IITs. Even at IITB I have observed many professors who don’t know their subjects well, and are not enthusiastic about teaching/research, I can just imagine what the situation might be like at other tier-2 or tier-3 institutes in India. It is about security, that, well, if you can clear IIT-JEE and come and study at IITs, you are studying in the best institute in India, and you can’t get anything better. And you know that you will end up fine in your life if you somehow get into IIT. After coming to IITB, there was always this sense of achievement in my head that whatever I am learning here, I am being taught by the best professors from India, and I am availing the best facilities an Indian student can get in India. The motivation and inspiration arises also from the fact that most of us are ignorant, and have no bigger dreams than IIT. Neither can most of our parents support education abroad. So, we have to put in our best to secure the best possible option in India. It is this mentality ingrained in us, that if we don’t get into IITs, our lives are screwed since at other places we will be getting less than par education. It is this fear instilled in us that compels us to study day and night. Moreover, I don’t want to sound pretentious, but once you delve deeper into IIT-JEE preparation, you are blinded by the fun of solving problems, taking tests and learning new things, and you study day and night because you actually enjoy it. PS- This answer does not want to imply that students studying at IITs are also the best and those studying in other institutes are not intelligent enough. I have seen extremely dimwitted people at IITs and super-brainy students at other institutes as well. What I wanted to convey through this post was that, in India, you cannot get a better deal than IITs, and that is what is the biggest encouraging factor.

I don’t know if this will sound pretentious, but i was motivated to study for IIT for one simple reason - I HAD NOTHING BETTER TO DO! Please do believe that I am not bragging here or trying to sound all brainy and stuff. Growing up, I had a lot of exposure to science, almost none to humanities or economics. Also, being one of the front benchers, I was misled to believe that I was intelligent. Come the 10th grade, I had finally decided to go with science as my majors and since we are in sweet ol India, I had to prepare for JEE. Believe it or not the 2 years of my JEE preparations were the best of my life. I am in IIT Roorkee right now and still there are days when I wish that I was back in Jaipur, preparing for JEE. I started out preparing for JEE because I did not know what way to go, but as my coaching progressed, I came to realize that whether I could crack JEE or not, I had found something for the first time in my life that I could do all day and still feel that I could go on, and that was solving JEE questions and learning mathematics and physics. I like to believe that I am not a nerd, just a lover of science. The way I see it, one can only find inspiration to put his all in JEE preperation is by falling in love with your academics. You don’t need to sacrifice other pleasures such as movies, sports, fun and stuff, you just need to realize that all of this will distract you from your goal. Also - learn and respect your own limitations and boundaries. JEE does require a certain IQ level for the different rank sets. I had realised early-on that I was not 3-digit rank material and that made my coaching years a lot easier. Don’t think of this as an ordeal that ends after 2 years, that just makes want to end it somehow, not in any way helping your efforts. Knowing where your interests lie and knowing your own capabilities will allo you to set an optimum target, and believe me, having cleared JEE I have realized that there is no greater joy than to earn something you worked hard for and yearned for, for about 2 years of your life. I got into IIT Roorkee, metallurgy and there is not a single day when i regret giving up some of my comforts during my JEE prep times. Here at IITR, everyday I learn something new (and not just academically), interact with the best people from all over the country, I have found friends that I love more than myself .I am optimistic about the furure, happy about the past and satisfied with my present and there is no greater joy in life. That might give you a little extra incentive to boost your preperations. :)

Here are some of the driving factors which can inspire students to study day and night to become an IITian. IITian’s SWAG-When they(aspirants) see their siblings/seniors or anyone wearing T-shirts or hoodies of their respective IITs ,they start staring at the “IIT” tag.They feel that one day they will wear T-shirts with the same “IIT” tag.This pic says it all…!!!  Seniors/Siblings-Students may get inspired by the success of their siblings or seniors of their coaching(or school).When they see the name and fame that their siblings are earning ,they just start imagining themselves in the same picture.They start preparing for JEE as early as possible.They become crazy to earn that name and fame which they would get if they get into IIT.Placements-Every year,few IIT Students(NOT all) bag whooping packages that are sometimes above 1 crore, from some big companies like Google, Facebook,Microsoft, etc.This creates a wrong perception among people that once you get into IIT,you will definitely get those big packages. It motivates them to work hard day and night so they would be able to fulfil their dreams.Jealousy-In our society, if any relative’s son or daughter gets selected in IIT ,then most of the parents feel jealous that why their child can’t do that?Jealousy imposes pressure on them that they start taking it as a matter of self- respect.Sometimes,they force their own child to work damn hard to get into IIT at any cost.Sometimes this jealousy gives fruitful results.But ,mostly students fail to work hard under pressure.This jealous feeling may also give painful results. It all depends upon on you whether you are just copying someone or you are really getting inspired. Don’t be jealous of anybody and ignore those so-called “Wellwishers” who don’t know anything about the exam.They won’t give you any valuable advice. Interact with your parents and teachers and get your problems sought out and make your own way to success… I hope this helps..!!!

Before I get to the inspiration part, I need to clear few doubts: Most IITians didn’t study day and night.Consistency plays a major role during preparation. This means that instead of studying 12 hours near the exam, study 4–6 hours daily peaking to 8 hours if necessary.I can say that most IITians are intelligent. That doesn’t mean all IITians are intelligent. Hard work also plays a major role.Be smart in your approach. Don’t waste too much time on a single topic. Focus on the basics.Practice as much as you can.Every topic is important.Let's move to how do IITians get inspiration: Most IITians are self motivated - you don't need to read motivational books and watch motivational videos to gain inspiration.Most IITians are sincere and responsible - once you have a goal in your mind, you do everything to achieve that.Parents have spent a lot on your education - As a token of respect, don’t let their hard work go in vain. Give them a reason to be proud of you.A good college can help you in the long run - IITs are recognized worldwide. Whether you aspire to earn money or do research, IIT tag can help you.The fees of IITs is relatively low compared to private colleges plus you get opportunities to secure various scholarships. - So if you are poor, this should work as an inspiration.IIT is a competitive environment - most of the students are smart and intelligent. You can gain knowledge and experience. At the same time, you are competing with them in academics.There are a lot of ways to get inspired. It is upto you to see them. Edit 1: I used the word IITians for the students who cleared JEE and got into IIT. Someone got confused if this is a guide to how IITians are, after they clear the exam.

Success stories of average students who topped IIT:- •Dungra Ram Choudhary: Hailing from a small village in Rajasthan, he supposedly dropped one year for better preparation. He breaks all the misconceptions that anyone hailing from a small town is no matching the others from bigger cities. His all India rank was 1. Pursued computer science from IIT Kanpur, and currently works at Oracle.  •Nikhil Garg: Just an above average student in school who did not like subjects that needed a lot of slogging. His all India rank was 6.He started preparing for IITJEE from class 11. He had joined Bansal coaching in Kota, and studies hard for two years. He pursued computer science from IIT Delhi, and presently works at Quora.  •Gaurav Soni: An average student who switched schools at a crucial time. He changed from a Hindi medium to an English medium school. Language difficulties let to poor grade, and worse performance. But he overcame it gradually, and obtained a good percentage in his board examination. He attended Resonance coaching classes in Kota, and kept rising to higher echelons as time passed. He cleared the JEE exam successfully, and chose chemical engineering IIT-Roorkee. •Rajiv Dandotiya : A government school student from a small town in Rajasthan, with no classrooms and where studying under a tree was the usual norm. He scored a staggeringly low percentage in his boards: 39 percent. After passing 12th, he helped his father with work. Small business dint click, and closed down soon. His board percentage made him ineligible for literally everything he was looking for. Then he stumbled across IITJEE. After borrowing a few prominent books and working out from them, but his poor English was a barrier. He cleared IITJEE in 2000, and tried again the next two years because the rank wasn’t satisfactory. He attended the exam the last time in 2002, and secured a rank of 1758. He pursued IEM at IIT, Kharagpur. •Amrose Birani: Didn’t get selected in his first attempt in 2006. But in his second attempt in 2007, he bagged an all India rank of 3. P.S:-If you are clear about your goal and your actions also speak in the same direction, then even your name could be included in the elite list of people who cleared IITJEEwork hard!! all the best :)

Some students are deeply inspired for cracking IIT Exam beacuse they've desire to do something big. Desire is the very big thing. Following are some daily life desire examples :— When your parents couldn't be able to fulfill their dream, you want to fulfill their dream and then you started working day and night for their dream. Man That's desireWhen your girlfriend rejected you beacuse you didn't have enough money,then you started working day and night to get her. Man that's desireWhen you want to travel abroad and want to enjoy your whole life, but you know that you can't do this thing without becoming successful then you started working day and night on your dream. Man that's desire.When you are not able to defeat a person in boxing, you want to defeat him/her then you started practicing day and night for it. Man that's desire.Desire is the thing that wakes up the people in the night to accomplish their dream.  This 6 letter word holds enormous power. You just need a powerful desire. Different people have different desire. You can see tons of desire in this world. To achieve anything you need burning desire. — Napoleon Hill God bless you with all kind of happiness.

India on the fastest wheels of education right now and when it comes to education in india IITs are just awesome and Jee is the only way to get into them.  The picture says it all and it is because in 2015 5 top places in india consecutively covered by iits so and reason behind that is extermely talented guys in iits because they had gone through one of the toughest exams in country…  The race continue in 2016 and IIT are rocking every year… So this is a small reason i can say there is something. Except this.. PLACEMENTS: i am presently studying at IIT KHARAGPUR and first thing that comes in my mind while preparing for JEE is their placement statistics. Very high payments in MNCs ,and a remarkable salary says it all.SWAG OF IITs IN LOCAL COMMUNITY: when your relatives and neighbours comes to know that you got admit in IIT they will took you out of this world and and you will become an unsung hero in a night, so every parents wants definitely the same..FACILITIES IN IIT : when you come to know about facilities in IIT they are just awesome…It is easy to say but standard of IITs is quiet higher then other nation institutes and they are rulling in the era of education.. COMPETITION FOR JEE … a strong reason for hardwork is the competition you are going to face is a little bit challanging because ….  This is the reason , for around nine thousand selection there are 14 lakhs aspirants so you just have to prepare hard for it… Best of luck for upcoming jee…

Students normally get inspired to study well to get into IIT in different ways. It all starts after your 10th. This is the scenario that normally happens in my state of Andhra Pradesh (combined state). Normally parents want their kids to be in good colleges. Students too look for their interest and then they see people in IIT who secured top jobs in the world. The pay check they get is really good. Parents start showing desire of getting their kid into IIT. After IITs are one of the prestigeous institutes for all. As students get inspiration from various sources like media, newspaper etc. they decide the join and IIT academy college. After going there in your first year you just happen to have a small desire to crack the IIT. But when you see the competition there, you will then feel whats in there for you. Student start competiting with others to get into top spots in college in weekly IIT exams. Once you see yourself in that spot among hundreds of people you start trusting your Calibre. Student would be afraid to loss the top spot and start working hard. Along with it, your professor who teach you tell you the success stories of the alumuni of the college. After all student decides cracking IIT is not impossible. These are all what I got inspired from while preparing for IIT.

Challenging problems… Don't think there can be one single answer here but all the people I met in college had one thing in common, they all loved getting a challenging problem and then keep going down the rabbit hole uncovering the solution. I must add that during our time (2004), final papers were subjective type so it wasn't always about speed. It wasn't like board examinations where you could score a 100% in almost all the papers; in JEE, it wasn't about trying to score a 100% but you had to be good enough to be able to solve enough number of problems in the limited time. People did leave with largely blank sheets. It was therefore possible to intelligently choose your battles and actually enjoy the exam. I remember being relaxed and satisfied with my effort while a lot of people were flipping out. You got to learn to enjoy it. Remember IITians are known to be analytical, most I know (including yours truly) have terrible memorization skills. So, it isn't really about how many hours you study. It also isn't about how many problems you (“mindlessly”) solve e.g: any idiot can keep multiplying single digit numbers all day without getting any better at multiplication. It really is about having struggled with enough variety of problems and then being able to connect the dots on the final day when it matters.  The fascinating thing about science is that the number of problems can be limitless and the journey of discovering answers is immensely satisfying to the people who enjoy it. The genuine candidates learn to enjoy the journey, that, more than anything else determines where they end up. image source: google

For few, the reasons are entirely about finances and relationships. I’ll tell you my story. It was in my 4th class. My mother was a school teacher and she told me that I should become an IITian. I never actually knew what exactly an IIT is, but the sheer love for her made it my dream. (Though dreaming of it in my 4th class didn’t matter and is silly). I have seen her work hard to sustain us and I would do anything for her. My father on the other hand used it in a another way. Whenever he around his friends, he would ask me what my dream was and I would reply “IIT Kharagpur Aeronautical Engineering” ( I still had no idea what it was) and I was prepared for the only other counter question people would ask “What is Aeronautical Engineering” I would reply ‘designing Aeroplanes” and that was enough to inspire them and make my father proud. Few Years down the line, I understood what IIT actually is and how to get into it. My mom being a physics teacher kept me interested in physics and I was good at maths, and there was no second thought about my destination. IIT coaching in my 11th and 12th class required huge amounts of money. My father had to sell the only remaining asset, our farmlands to pay for this. A farmer treats his land on par with his mother and it was a hard decision. So everyday of my IIT coaching I knew I needed to work for me, my parents, their hard work and their sacrifices. Some of their Sacrifices and Hardships: My mom was the first to protest and shift us from a village to a town to get us proper education. It was a huge step considering our finances. She managed it with odd jobs.My mom worked as a teacher for more than 15 years in private schools, Every single penny utilised to feed us and educate us.My father worked for several years in fields for the same reasons.I remember hundreds of times they starved to feed us, they didn’t sleep as they couldn’t pay our fees in time.“ If the troubles faced by your parents to provide you with food, to educate you and their sacrifices don’t motivate you, Nothing else in world would” Have to go Anonymous as I got too emotional and revealed a little more than intended. (IIT Madras Mech 2014 Pass out)

Firstly remove your concept of studying day and night, To clear JEE, what you require is systematic way of approach and above all, time management including few extra-currica that you really love. Health should always be the priority, take my example, I gave the JEE under 103F fever, but since I prepared for the continuous two years of preparations, it paid off!! (I still regret that day). Now, coming to the inspiration point, IIT is not for you if you haven't got the guts to show dedication to the tasks given to you, assignments, papers. If you are aware of this then comes next is how you handle failures. By admitting yourselves into IIT, you are letting yourselves open to all the vast amenities and opportunities that it provides. This in itself is a greatest inspiration you can have!! Once you see this broader picture, small stumbles like less marks in a test won't matter much!! Last but not the least, biggest inspiration is YOU!!, spend every day in front of the mirror to ensure that the one guy who can do it is you Go! Do it!!

Warning: This is a long answer and it's written because I hope it serves as a eye opener to the people running behind engineering blindly. I think the real inspiration is the lifestyle/money that follows after you graduate from the IITs. People only see the packages that IITians get during the placements. Most of the students don't even have a slight idea of what is going to be taught in their branch/field. A funny example of this is when a student has to choose his field in engineering, he chooses what is available(computer science being the top priority) rather than going for what he likes(but I think it's justified since he does not know what he's going to get in those branches as a result of choosing engineering blindly). Unfortunately this is the case in India because there is no counselling from school/parents side in order to make a choice where the student chooses a field in which he's interested rather than going blind and appearing for JEE no matter what they like. I hear people saying IITs take only the cream students. That's okay as far as engineering field is concerned but does that mean the other people are mediocre or useless ? NO. They are probably good or even better than those IITians in other things like it sports, music, arts, law, health, cinema, fashion and many other fields. I think the real cream is our sportspersons who despite no real motivation from society, perform at the international level and win. People like these are the real cream in my opinion whereas the ones who perform well at JEE are making big bucks but not innovating in their field, which is what is expected of them. There are so many fields to choose from. We can do so much better in other areas. But like they say, in India, a student first chooses engineering and then figures out what to do in life rather than choosing it before wasting their four crucial years of life. As a result of which we lose so much talent. This very reason that student, even the so called cream layer of students, runs behind the fame and money while choosing the IITs is responsible for IITs being the best in country but not even recognized at international level(with exception of a few) because they care about the research work and innovation that happens in a college and not the the merit list/cutoff while admitting. Their admition process is also very different where a crucial part of admitting a student is SOP(Stament of Purpose) where the reason to take that particular field is to be stated. If the reason is strong and real than the motivation will come naturally and we won't have someone even ask this question in the first place. Here's what Narayan Murthy(an IITian and former Infosys CEO) said during a visit in IISc. Bangalore- “Our youngsters have not done much impactful research work despite being equal to their counterparts in intellect and energy in Western universities” And I totally agree with him. We all know Indians are very intelligent people but still no hardcore innovation at international level. Reason ? I don't know. But it has something to do with how our college system works. One of my teacher said we have probably the best schooling system in the world but one of the worst college education system as well because we continue to teach them in the same manner like schools. Thanks for sparing a few minutes to read this. The answer was not exactly what was asked in the question. My only point in writing all this is we need to focus more on what we like rather than what is expected of you from society/parents. If that was the case you would not need motivation for something you don't like in the first place. PS: This also happens to be my first answer on quora. I hope you like it(or at least don't hate it). Thanks Edit: I see other people answering that siblings' achievement, IITian tag, jealousy are the some of the reasons to follow the IIT dream. While these are the correct reasons, we seriously need to think if this is what it has come down to ? IIT tag ? Seriously ? I don't see any reason why they don't follow a good film director tag or a good musician tag, or a good lawyer tag, or a good sportsperson tag. Because there isn't a examination for that ? Because the path requires struggle and seems difficult (not as straightforward as writing a single paper). In that sense people choose IIT not because it's tough to crack and to get some sense of achievement but because it seems like a shortcut to success. Give an exam and be successful. They don't want to choose other fields because they'll probably need more years of hard work and an undefined path to excel. IITians are like cricketers, they have a great following but this is not the only game. I've already said this that we need to focus more on other sports (fields) than cricket because it's a highly overrated game, so are IITians and I think we need not look up at them so much and also need to look up at other fields.

I appreciate and thank Prateek Rai for this R2A. Though I could’t crack it myself, but I would try to do justice here. There may be many factors that inspire them so deeply: Ambience: If you are in Kota, you will be literally forced to give your best. By the time time, you would solve 10 questions of any chapter, your friends may have solved the whole of the book. The syllabus go so fast. The assignments may pile up if you are slow and negligent. And of course your parents are paying too much for the tuition. Ultimately, you will try hard and try to race up for the targets set.Parents’ education: There is one thing that needs to be noticed. Generally the topper candidates’ guardian do have a very strong educational background. Their father are like ‘MS from Cornell’ or ‘MBBS from AIIMS’ or ‘M.Tech from Roorkee’. I admit that many students from humble background have done tremendously well. But get the proportional data and the figures will amaze you. If the parents have done good in their time, their offspring will make it better.Relatives and friends: If you have someone who had cleared IIT in his/her time and he/she is doing pretty well in their life, parents throw the whole credit to their graduation degree. And truly, you may often see the contrast between those who made it to IIT and those who couldn’t. I am not giving any verdict and not tarring every wall with the same brush. But many alike examples can be found.Passion: Few people just do it because they want to. They don’t know how things are going to work but they do because they want to. You may not tell the exact answer to their ‘Why’ but they are just smashing their head day and night to get their equations straightened up and make it to the Cut off list. They just do it.Infrastructure: Visit your local college and then Visit IIT Kharagpur. I am just convincing you to take a train and visit the campus. You will find ample reasons for that ‘Why’Hope it helps. Thanks.

I got an air of 3183 in jee advanced 2016.And yes the biggest problem that i came through during those jee days was to feel motivated.Here are the techniques that kept me motivated. When my mind choked mugging up formulas and solving problems,i used to close my eyes and imagined what would happen if i am able to bag a great rank in jee. I imagined myself in the centre with juniors around me asking me the methodology of success,my coaching rewarding me for my great success .Just imagine how great you will feel on the result day when the media would be striving hard to get your interview done.Every known and unknown relatives will call and congratulate you and your parents for your success.Seriously you will act as an ideal to your relatives and neighbours.I cant tell about the girls… but you will have a huge fan following of aunties for sure.Just imagine how great it feels to see your parents feeling proud of you… yes their hard work and proper mentorship has paid.Note-If you wanna feel all these points in your life then you need to bag a great rank such as a 2 digit rank or atleast a 3 digit rank.Hope this helps you.

My Dad used to say these lines. Son ,there are three kind of people in the world. One who stay on the top, others who are mediocre and ones who end up last. Do you know who has more regret in his life? The mediocre ones. Don’t be in that group. Either be on the top or end up last.Revenge is another good motivator. In my case some teachers used to think of me as this useless chap. My physics teacher once said to me “Dude, you can’t even solve simple shit and you dream of an IIT .” He said it in such a tone that I was shattered. Now the only reason I used to study was to show what I really am.Introverts crave attention. Believe it or not it’s true. You don’t want to be known as this useless chap.You don’t know what else to do in life. The only reason I took IIT-JEE because I didn’t know what else to do. I hated biology but was decent in academics. So medical was out of question and the other field left was Non-medical(anyways being from a small town I didn’t know much about any other fields)You are tempted towards their lifestyle after reading Five Point Someone. Three friends enjoying and helping each other in every aspect of the college life.

It is the passion that make you do any tough task. Passion exceeds talent, intelligence, IQ, everything. It is motivation for those guys who are working for 15hrs a day to get a seat at the IIT’S. Passion is the motivation, driving force, that brings the determination in those guys. Nothing great can be achieved from when you are in comfort zone, to achieve you have to come out of comfort zone, leave procrastination. Passion leads you to your goal. And second thing is an defeated, desperate person is more ferocious than a lion. Droppers who give a try once again are more dangerous, they are focused,finely tuned, more desperate and perfectly directed. Every year those who make into iit Droppers share about 58% (almost 60%) Again it the passion that motivated these Droppers to try once again.

See this question does not have a stable answer as the inspiration of every head differs from situation to situation. I mean some people have a strong desire to get into India's most prestigious and best institutes while many may crave it for the handsome packages.The motivation differs from person to person but the main motive still remains a place and that is the lucrative facilities and environment that a student of a good government college gets as compared to that of the other colleges.Sometimes it may be the dream of some parents and for the sake of their wishes a child may pick up his/her interest in this field.Many times the subjects become the motive of the hard work when you are in love with the subjects and that too when your mentors are the most experienced and dedicated professionals.Nowadays there are many online and offline platforms available for following the JEE syllabus with ease under the comfort zones.One of those under my suggestion is the Ahaguru online course which builds an urge to get and work with science and concepts.At last, since I have also been through the same phase and landed successfully at NIT Allahabad, I know it’s the daily dedication and determination that allows the aspirants to walk beyond the comfort zones.

Well, I’ll be really honest while answering this question. Most of the people who choose to prepare for JEE till that point have absolutely no idea about what do they want to do in life. In India its plainly asked, “Beta doctor Banoge ya Engineer”. People who like Maths go for Engineering, while the ones who hate maths go for MBBS. So nothing comes from within in the beginning. Some of your friends have already started preparing for JEE and “Mai bhi aata hun” attitude gets most of the folks into coaching institutes. There is no such magic but FEAR and COMPETITION that can keep you motivated for two years or more for working so hard. Fear to not get selected and competition in the classroom. Honestly only two types of people get through JEE, absolute brilliant ones and the average folks who fear failure. Interest and all such stuff is absolute rubbish. Another thing which I felt in my JEE days was that with time when your parents start dedicating themselves for your results, that is what pushes you, you start doing it for them. You see your mother taking extra care of your diet, father staying up late in light to make sure that you do not fall asleep while studying. These are the things that probably push you the most to pull it off. Although one trait is extremely important and that is HONESTY, to yourself most importantly. Because you’ll never question yourself until you are not honest, questioning oneself is probably the most important thing that keeps you going for this long.

I will answer this question, having some indirect experience as my son went to an IIT. Interestingly he had a fairly straightforward, unstressful routine. He also did not attend the coaching mills at Hyderabad/Kota. The IIT’s are aspirational institutions because of the following reasons: 1. The infrastructure is excellent 2. The Professors are qualified and do good research 3. Students are serious and intelligent The above three set the stage for a good education as compared to most other engineering colleges which have a dearth of the above three. In addition: Placements are excellentUniversities in the United States give due credence to an IIT student, in terms of admission, grants, assistant-ships and other financial grantsThe IIT output has a lifelong advantage in terms of brand.In conclusion, they have an early career advantage over students from other colleges. Cheers/ Prof: Nagaraj Subbarao

These students are inspired either by : Their current problems (Financial, Lack of exposure, mundane life, small town / city, less opportunities, less growth & so on)Their goal of getting into IIT where they get access to Great Peer Group, Very organized academics, huge opportunities for internships & jobs, career in research, world class research facilities, journals & professors, vast alumni network spread across the world, proving in 1 exam leads to cascading effect of proving at other places & so onOverall preparation journey is worth it because we actually experience that ‘Limits exist only in our minds’

Every effort has a purpose behind it. In your case it is quite clear….congrats….. But….if you are not putting effort then it's not your purpose. 1. Dream of the scene that would create at your home if you get into IIT. 2. Think of the underprivileged that could be benefited if they get the resources you are enjoying. Don’t waste the resources. 3. What if you couldn’t make into IITs or NITs….what next. If 100 student “so-called” fails in JEE, out of them 70–75 take admissions in private colleges. Even a mediocre college will charge you 2–3 lakhs per annum for giving you the degree. 4. Of course, you can touch sky even if you couldn’t make in IITs or NITs…. only difference would be that you will not get the stage ... you have to run behind it. 5. Remember, ***it’s okay to be late but worst to regret.*** Rest all depends on you, there is ample external motivation out there but only internal motivation will remain with you forever. Good luck….

MOTIVATION TO KEEP STUDYING FOR IIT — Search on the internet, the top positions in the world. You will find that they are occupied by many IITians.. this will keep you boosted for the entire journeyKeep watching movies like Chak de India, Guru, Suryavansham, Om Jai Jagdish etc from time to timeAlways give some time for yourself (enjoyment) when you are studying in between .. This will get you back into higher spiritsTalk to other people studying in IIT and know about its life.. You will find that life at IIT is so good!! You can grow overall at IIT (be it studies, sports, music and other activities). So IIT can give you really good base for the future ! This thing will keep you motivated..Best Wishes Satnara IIT AIIMS Academy (an initiative by IITians.. :) ) Mayur Vihar, Delhi

1.Many of engineering aspirants have a basic aim that is money and success. Now you might be knowing the highest, average paclage being given at placement season. Even an average guy would land up around 7.2 lpa. Most of them think that getting into an iit is assurity that they will get a high paying job (which they will(at least 4 lpa which is more than avg. Of tier 2 colleges)). 2. Reservation system because of which general caste students need to devote 4x time a studious reserved category guy would . 3. To be like sharma ji ka beta or beat sharma ji ka beta. 4. Getting into iit will make you popular among relatives(mere/i beta/i ka achche clg me admission) or say parental pressure.

Every effort has a purpose behind it. But….if you are not putting effort then it's not your purpose. Your mind and your whole body should work in sync. 1. Dream of the scene that would create at your home if you get into IIT. 2. Think of the underprivileged that could be benefited if they would get the resources you are enjoying. Don’t waste the resources. 3. What if you couldn’t make into IITs or NITs….what next. If 100 student “so-called” fails in JEE, out of them 70–75 take admissions in private colleges. Even a mediocre college will charge you 2–3 lakhs per year. 4. Of course, you can touch sky even if you couldn’t make in IITs or NITs…. only difference would be, you will not get the stage ... you will have to run behind it. 5. Remember, ***it’s okay to be late but worst to regret.*** Rest all depends on you, there is ample external motivation out there but only internal motivation will help you to achieve what you desire, ignite the inner engine, gear up your body to perform extreme!!!! One Day or Day One, there is a difference. Good luck….

There is not much people who really get inspired by iit. Since the level of maturity is low. Some people who are born prodigy are capable of inspiration but most of the students are simply inspired becoz they have been infected by a worm of the typical competitive environment and start traveling along with everyone else. Studying day and night is done by only some students who are really interested in it. But it is not necessary to have such a heavy duty of having nite outs and making life difficult.

There are many possibilities here : case 1: We all hear about so many media reports that talk about 1/2/3 crore packages that most of us have an illusion that the IIT tag helps us to become filthy rich. so many see this degree as an opportunity to earn more money . The hunger to lead a better lifestyle and earn more money drives some . case 2: Coaching institute teachers put a lot of pressure and in many places students who don't score well are not even treated with dignity and respect(I have personally experienced this in the first few months of 11th grade when I struggled to grasp concepts ) . so this experience definitely fires them up to study incessantly. case 3: This case applies to a section of people who are genuinely interested in what they learn and put in their best effort to master what they learn.

It is merely due to the pressure of the society. You cannot expect a kid of 14/15 years to be mature and conscious enough of all the opportunities in life. IIT is presented as the best means to achieve success in life. The author of 'Small is beautiful’ points out that the real aim of education is to “strive after something thought of as good”. Most people end up their life w/o discovering their noble strive. This is precisely the reason why people often feel EMPTY despite all the successes in life. Hence, try discovering your strive - something on which you can work for next 4/5 decades, you will be successfully.

Think about the result, in news that you have qualified exam getting selected in your dream collage.Think about parent,who will be very happy by your achievement. Also about the very bad situation after exam you have not achieved anything.Collages are not giving admission to you. These things will be driving factor to do your work religiously with greater effectiveness.

You never inspire anyone to do something you think is good for them. You let them do it themselves. How do you even know IIT is their cup of tea? Once inspired anyone can attain anything, but it should never be fake inspiration.

The fact is that IITS provide the best placement options for the students. The privileges students get are secondary, they don't even know about them before entering the college. Most of the students belong to the middle class family, so it is natural for everyone​ student to prepare for IIT and secure a job after 4 years, along with the other privileges included.

Let me explain to use how to get motivated to study for iit ieve if you aren’t still motivated to do so. First of all i’m not aged enough to give you an advice so see this as an advice from your little brother on behalf of our age If I’m standing in your space “i will suggest you to move on” because life is all about hunting. you will get what you hunt for..

There are many reasons such as - Many students want to see their life at its best.Some belong to not so good financial background and do a lot of hard work to improve their life and life of their hardworking studentsSome want to do research , so they want to get into the IIT'S
That is the difference between Passion and rote learning.
Everybody has its own story, generally toppers are self motivated But for the motivation watch the video of Sandeep maheshwari Dr. Vivek bendra Or watch this video about sundar pichai till the end
